title: Web Development Step by Step
text: Preface

title: Web Development Step by Step
section: Building for Business in the AI Era
text:
Building for Business in the AI Era
Welcome to Web Development Step by Step: Building Business Solutions with AI – a practical guide to modern web development that embraces AI as your development partner while never losing sight of why we build: to solve real business problems.

Why This Book Is Different
Most web development books teach you technologies. This book teaches you to think like a professional developer who happens to use specific technologies.
In a world where AI can generate code in seconds, the valuable skills are:

Understanding what to build – translating business needs into technical requirements
Evaluating technology choices – knowing when WordPress beats React, or vice versa
Communicating with stakeholders – explaining technical decisions in business terms
Iteratively improving – knowing when “good enough” ships and when quality matters

This book develops these skills while teaching you HTML, CSS, JavaScript, WordPress, and React.


The AI Partnership
AI can write HTML, CSS, and JavaScript faster than you ever will. That’s not a threat – it’s a superpower.
This book teaches you to:

Architect solutions that AI helps you build
Evaluate AI output with professional judgment
Communicate requirements clearly enough for AI to help
Debug and improve AI-generated code

You’re learning to be the architect. AI is your highly skilled assistant.


About This Book’s Creation
In the spirit of practicing what we teach, this book was created through human-AI collaboration. Every chapter represents a partnership between human expertise and AI assistance, with careful human oversight ensuring pedagogical quality and technical accuracy.


Your Learning Journey
Over 12 weeks (or at your own pace), you’ll progress from understanding web fundamentals to building integrated business applications. More importantly, you’ll develop the professional judgment that makes you valuable in any technology stack.


Who This Book Is For

Students in business technology or web development courses
Career changers entering tech from business backgrounds
Professionals who need to understand web development for their roles
Anyone who wants to build web solutions with AI assistance



Prerequisites

Basic computer literacy
Curiosity about how websites work
Willingness to experiment and learn from mistakes
Access to AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, or similar)

No prior programming experience required. We start from scratch.


How to Use This Book
Each chapter follows a consistent pattern:

Concept First – Understand the idea before the syntax
AI Exploration – Discover patterns with AI assistance
Hands-On Practice – Build something real
Business Connection – Understand why this matters
Reflection – Consolidate your learning

Work through chapters in order. Each builds on the previous.


Companion Course
This book aligns with ISYS3004: Business Web and Mobile Technologies at Curtin University, but stands alone as a complete learning resource.

title: Web Development Step by Step
text:
Related Resources
This book is part of a “Learning with AI” collection – resources designed to help you master modern development in the AI era.

The AI Methodology Guide
Intentional Prompting: Mastering the Human-AI Development Process provides the deep methodology for AI collaboration that this book applies to web development. If you want to understand why certain prompting approaches work, Intentional Prompting is your guide.
Key concepts from Intentional Prompting used throughout this book:

The Six-Step Methodology: Restate → Identify I/O → Work by Hand → Pseudocode → Convert → Test
Design before coding: Understanding problems before asking AI for solutions
Intentional prompts: Directing AI with clarity and purpose
Critical evaluation: Reviewing AI output with professional judgment



The Python Track
If you’re also interested in Python development, explore the Python learning path:

Python Step by Step with AI: For absolute beginners learning computational thinking
Python Jumpstart: Focused Python fundamentals with AI integration
From Zero to Production: Professional Python development practices



Book Progression
                    ┌─────────────────────┐
                    │    INTENTIONAL      │
                    │     PROMPTING       │
                    │   (Methodology)     │
                    └─────────────────────┘
                           │
            ┌──────────────┼──────────────┐
            ▼              │              ▼
    ┌───────────────┐      │      ┌───────────────┐
    │  PYTHON TRACK │      │      │   WEB TRACK   │
    │               │      │      │               │
    │ Step by Step  │      │      │ Web Dev Step  │
    │ Jumpstart     │      │      │ by Step       │
    │ Zero to Prod  │      │      │ (this book)   │
    └───────────────┘      │      └───────────────┘
                           │
                    (shared methodology)
Start wherever matches your goals. The methodology from Intentional Prompting enhances all paths.

Let’s build something meaningful together.

title: Weekly Reading List
text:
Reading Tips

Don’t read everything - Focus on Essential Reading first
Hands-on over theory - Try examples as you read
MDN is your friend - Best for accurate, detailed explanations
web.dev for modern practices - Google’s recommendations
W3Schools for quick reference - Fast examples, less depth
Use AI to explain - If an article is confusing, ask AI to explain it differently

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.1 A New Way to Build for the Web
Right now, AI can write HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in seconds. It can create entire websites, debug code, and explain complex concepts. So why learn web development at all?
Here’s the truth: AI is incredible at writing code, but it doesn’t understand what your business needs. You’re the architect, the translator between business requirements and technical solutions. AI is your highly skilled assistant who needs clear direction.
This book teaches you to be that architect.
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.3 What This Experiment Teaches Us

AI defaults to complexity – It assumes you want a “complete” solution
Your prompts shape your learning – Clear learning goals get clearer responses
Concepts before code – You can use AI to understand ideas before syntax
You’re in control – AI follows your lead, not the other way around
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.4 The Three Learning Strategies
Throughout this book, we’ll follow three core strategies:

Strategy 1: Understand the Concept Before the Code
Every web development task follows patterns. Understand the pattern first, then learn how HTML/CSS/JavaScript expresses it.
Example: Don’t ask “How do I make a navigation menu?” Instead, ask “What is the purpose of navigation on a website?” Then, “Show me the simplest HTML navigation.”


Strategy 2: Use AI to Explore, Not to Avoid Learning
AI is your exploration tool. Use it to:

See different approaches to the same problem
Understand why code works
Compare technologies
Debug your understanding



Strategy 3: Build Mental Models, Not Just Working Websites
A working website isn’t the goal. Understanding how and why it works is. Use AI to build these mental models.
Example: Ask “Draw a diagram showing how HTML, CSS, and JavaScript work together” or “Explain responsive design using a newspaper analogy.”
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
section: 1.5 How AI Thinks vs How Developers Think
text:
1.5 How AI Thinks vs How Developers Think

AI Thinks in Patterns

It has seen millions of websites
It pattern-matches to give you a “typical” solution
It doesn’t understand your specific business context
It can’t know what you don’t know yet



Developers Think in Problems

What exactly needs to be solved?
Who is the user?
What’s the simplest solution?
How will this be maintained?
What could go wrong?

Your job is to bridge this gap: Think like a developer, then guide AI to help you implement.
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.6 Your Progressive AI Journey

Part I (Chapters 1-4): AI as Concept Explorer
Example prompts:
- "Explain semantic HTML using a library analogy"
- "Show me 5 ways CSS can position elements, simplest first"
- "What happens when a user clicks a button? Explain the event flow"


Part II (Chapters 5-8): AI as Implementation Assistant
Example prompts:
- "I need a WordPress theme for a café. What questions should I ask before choosing?"
- "Compare these two plugins for contact forms. What are the trade-offs?"
- "Explain REST APIs as if I'm explaining to a business stakeholder"


Part III (Chapters 9-11): AI as Code Producer
Example prompts:
- "Create a React component that displays a list of products. Here's my design..."
- "Convert this WordPress post display to a React component"
- "Review this code for accessibility issues"


Part IV (Chapters 12-14): AI as Strategic Advisor
Example prompts:
- "Compare PWAs vs native apps for a small retail business"
- "What should a junior developer's portfolio demonstrate?"
- "What web technologies should I learn next, given I know X, Y, Z?"
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.7 The Honest Truth
By the end of this book:

AI will still write code faster than you ✓
But you’ll know what to ask for ✓
You’ll understand what it gives you ✓
You’ll fix it when it’s wrong ✓
You’ll explain it to stakeholders ✓
You’ll be the architect, not the typist ✓

This is not a consolation prize. This is the actual job of a modern web developer.
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.8 Exercises






NoteExercise Levels




Level 1: Direct application
Level 2: Minor modifications
Level 3: Combining concepts
Level 4: Problem-solving
Level 5: Open-ended design




Exercise 0.1: Prompt Evolution (Level 1)
Start with “website” and evolve your prompt through 4 iterations to get the simplest possible “About Us” page. Document each iteration and what changed.


Exercise 0.2: Concept Extraction (Level 2)
Ask AI to explain “responsive design” three different ways: 1. Using a technical explanation 2. Using a real-world analogy 3. Using a business justification
Which helped you understand best? Why?


Exercise 0.3: AI Comparison (Level 3)
Ask the same question to two different AI tools (or the same tool twice). Compare the responses. What’s consistent? What differs? What does this tell you about using AI?


Exercise 0.4: Business Translation (Level 4)
A client says: “I want a website that looks professional and works on phones.”
Write three different AI prompts that would help you: 1. Clarify what “professional” means 2. Understand their mobile requirements 3. Explore technology options


Exercise 0.5: AI Learning Plan (Level 5)
Design your personal AI learning strategy for this book: 1. What kinds of prompts will you start with? 2. How will you verify AI’s answers? 3. What questions will you ask to deepen understanding? 4. How will you track what you’ve learned?
Create a “My AI Partnership Plan” document.
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.9 Chapter Summary

AI is your learning partner, not your replacement
Clear prompts lead to clear learning
Understanding concepts matters more than memorising syntax
You’re learning to be an architect who uses AI as a tool
Business context shapes everything in web development
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.10 Reflection
Before moving to Chapter 1, ensure you:

Completed the Partnership Experiment
Understand why AI overcomplicates by default
Can evolve prompts from vague to learning-focused
See yourself as an architect, not a code typist
Have a plan for using AI as a learning partner
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.11 Your Learning Journal
Start your learning journal now. For this chapter, record:

Partnership Experiment Results: What surprised you about AI’s responses?
Best Prompt: Which prompt got you the most useful response?
Mental Model: How do you now think about AI as a development partner?
Business Question: What kind of web solutions do you want to build?
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner
text:
1.12 Next Steps
In Chapter 1, we’ll explore how web pages are structured using HTML. You’ll use your new prompt skills to discover semantic markup – the foundation of everything we build. We’ll start with the concept of “documents as structured information” before writing a single line of code.
Remember: You’re not learning to code. You’re learning to think like a web professional who directs AI to help build solutions. Let’s begin!
crumbs: 1  Understanding Your AI Web Development Partner

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.1 The Concept First
Before we write any HTML, let’s understand what we’re really doing: organising information so both humans and machines can understand it.
A web page is a document. Like any document – a book, a report, a menu – it has structure. HTML is simply the language we use to describe that structure.
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.2 Understanding Through Architecture
Think of a building:

The foundation supports everything
Walls divide space into meaningful areas
Signs tell you what each area is for
Doors connect different spaces

HTML works the same way. Elements create structure. Tags label what things are.
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
section: 2.3 Discovering Structure with Your AI Partner
text:
2.3 Discovering Structure with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Document Anatomy
Ask your AI:
If I showed you a restaurant menu, what structural elements would you identify? Don't use any HTML terms yet.


Exploration 2: Semantic Meaning
Ask your AI:
Explain "semantic HTML" using a library catalog analogy


Exploration 3: Simplest Page
Ask your AI:
Show me the absolute simplest valid HTML page with just a heading and paragraph
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

text:
2.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Basic HTML structure, semantic elements]
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.5 Business Applications
Why structure matters for business:

SEO: Search engines understand structured content
Accessibility: Screen readers navigate structure
Maintenance: Well-structured pages are easier to update
Professionalism: Structure reflects organisational thinking
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

2.7 Chapter Summary

HTML describes document structure
Semantic elements convey meaning
Structure serves both humans and machines
Good structure is a business asset
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.8 Reflection

Can explain HTML’s purpose without using technical jargon
Understand semantic vs. presentational markup
Can identify structural elements in any document
See how structure serves business goals
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.9 Your Learning Journal
[Prompts to be developed]
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture
text:
2.10 Next Steps
In Chapter 2, we’ll explore CSS – how to control the visual presentation of our structured content. Structure and presentation are deliberately separate, and understanding why is key to professional web development.
crumbs: 2  Structure: HTML as Information Architecture

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
text:
3.1 The Concept First
CSS controls how structured content looks. But it’s more than decoration – it’s visual communication. Colours, spacing, and layout convey meaning, guide attention, and build trust.
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
text:
3.2 Understanding Through Design
Think of two cafés with identical menus but different interiors. The food is the same (content), but the atmosphere (presentation) creates completely different experiences.
CSS is your atmosphere.
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
section: 3.3 Discovering Presentation with Your AI Partner
text:
3.3 Discovering Presentation with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Separation of Concerns
Ask your AI:
Why do we separate HTML (structure) from CSS (presentation)? Explain using a newspaper analogy.


Exploration 2: Mobile-First
Ask your AI:
Explain mobile-first design as a business strategy, not just a technical approach


Exploration 3: Visual Hierarchy
Ask your AI:
How does visual hierarchy guide user attention? Show me with a simple example.
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
text:
3.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: CSS basics, selectors, box model, flexbox, responsive design]

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
text:
3.5 Business Applications

Brand consistency: CSS enforces visual standards
User experience: Good design builds trust
Mobile reach: Responsive design serves all devices
Conversion: Visual hierarchy guides users to action
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

CSS controls visual presentation
Mobile-first is a business strategy

Presentation and structure serve different purposes
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

3.8 Reflection

crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication
text:
3.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 3, we’ll add behaviour with JavaScript – making pages respond to user actions. Structure, presentation, and behaviour form the three pillars of web development.
crumbs: 3  Presentation: CSS as Visual Communication

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.1 The Concept First
HTML provides structure. CSS provides presentation. JavaScript provides behaviour – the ability to respond to user actions, update content dynamically, and create interactive experiences.
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.2 Understanding Through Conversation
A static page is like a poster. JavaScript makes your page more like a conversation – it listens, responds, and adapts.
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
section: 4.3 Discovering Behaviour with Your AI Partner
text:
4.3 Discovering Behaviour with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Event-Driven Thinking
Ask your AI:
Explain event-driven programming using a restaurant service analogy


Exploration 2: DOM Manipulation
Ask your AI:
What is the DOM? Explain it as if describing how a librarian rearranges books.


Exploration 3: Progressive Enhancement
Ask your AI:
Why should websites work without JavaScript? Explain the business case.
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Variables, functions, events, DOM manipulation, async basics]
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.5 Business Applications

User engagement: Interactive features increase engagement
Form validation: Prevent errors before submission
Dynamic content: Update without page reload
Analytics: Track user behaviour
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.7 Chapter Summary

JavaScript enables interaction
Event-driven thinking is fundamental
Progressive enhancement ensures accessibility
Behaviour enhances but shouldn’t replace structure
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction
text:
4.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 4, we’ll connect to the world through APIs – fetching data from other services and sending data to servers. This transforms standalone pages into connected applications.
crumbs: 4  Behaviour: JavaScript as User Interaction

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.1 The Concept First
No system exists in isolation. APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) allow different systems to communicate – your website can display weather data, process payments, or sync with inventory systems.
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.2 Understanding Through Contracts
An API is like a contract between systems. It says: “If you send me this, I’ll give you that.” Both sides agree on the format, and communication flows.
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
section: 5.3 Discovering Connection with Your AI Partner
text:
5.3 Discovering Connection with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: API Analogy
Ask your AI:
Explain REST APIs using a restaurant ordering system analogy


Exploration 2: Data Formats
Ask your AI:
Why is JSON the standard format for API data? What problem does it solve?


Exploration 3: Error Handling
Ask your AI:
What can go wrong when calling an API? How should a professional application handle each case?
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: fetch(), JSON, async/await, error handling, CORS basics]
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.5 Business Applications

Data integration: Connect to business systems
Third-party services: Payments, maps, analytics
Real-time updates: Live data without refresh
Scalability: Separate frontend from backend
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.7 Chapter Summary

APIs enable system integration
HTTP methods have specific purposes
Error handling is professional practice
JSON is the common language
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration
text:
5.9 Next Steps
You’ve now covered the foundations: HTML (structure), CSS (presentation), JavaScript (behaviour), and APIs (connection). In the Portfolio Project, you’ll combine these skills to build a complete portfolio website. Then we move to Part II, where we explore content management systems.
crumbs: 5  Connection: APIs as Business Integration

title: 6  Project: Portfolio Website
text:
6.1 Project Overview
Build a personal portfolio website demonstrating your mastery of HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and API integration.
Aligned with: Assessment 1 in ISYS3004

title: 6  Project: Portfolio Website
text:
6.2 Learning Outcomes Addressed

ULO 1: Design and implement effective web applications
ULO 3: Analyse requirements to inform design
ULO 5: Evaluate web technologies

title: 6  Project: Portfolio Website
text:
6.3 Requirements

Functional Requirements

Home page with introduction
About page with background
Projects/Work showcase
Contact information
Responsive design (mobile, tablet, desktop)
API integration (e.g., GitHub projects, weather widget)



Technical Requirements

Semantic HTML5
CSS with mobile-first approach
JavaScript for interactivity
API data fetching
Accessibility basics (WCAG 2.1 AA)

title: 6  Project: Portfolio Website
text:

Document your AI collaboration:

What prompts helped most?
What did you modify from AI suggestions?
What did AI get wrong?
What did you learn through the collaboration?

[To be developed: Rubric]

Source code repository
AI collaboration log
Reflection document

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.1 The Concept First
In Part I, you built pages by writing code. But who updates that content? A CMS (Content Management System) separates content from code, allowing non-technical users to manage their own websites.
This is a business decision, not just a technical one.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.2 Understanding Through Roles
Think about a newspaper. Writers create content. Editors review it. Designers create templates. Each role focuses on what they do best.
A CMS enables this separation for websites.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
section: 7.3 Discovering CMS with Your AI Partner
text:
7.3 Discovering CMS with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Build vs Buy
Ask your AI:
When should a business build a custom website vs use a CMS? Create a decision framework.


Exploration 2: Stakeholder Analysis
Ask your AI:
Who are the stakeholders in a website project? What does each need from a CMS?


Exploration 3: Content Strategy
Ask your AI:
Explain content strategy for a small business website. What questions should we answer first?
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: CMS types, WordPress overview, content modelling]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 3 – translating stakeholder needs into requirements.

Client handoff: Clients can update their own content
Reduced maintenance: Content changes don’t require developers
Governance: Control who can change what
Scalability: Add content without code changes
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.7 Chapter Summary

CMS separates content from code
Stakeholder needs drive CMS choice
Content strategy precedes technology
The right CMS reduces long-term costs
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content
text:
7.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 6, we’ll dive into WordPress – the CMS powering over 40% of the web. We’ll understand it as a platform, not just a blogging tool.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business
7  Why CMS? The Business Value of Managed Content

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.1 The Concept First
WordPress isn’t just blogging software – it’s a platform with an ecosystem of themes, plugins, and APIs. Understanding WordPress as a platform helps you make better technology decisions.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.2 Understanding Through Ecosystems
Think of WordPress like a smartphone. The core provides basics, but the app ecosystem makes it powerful. Choosing the right “apps” (plugins/themes) is as important as the platform itself.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
section: 8.3 Discovering WordPress with Your AI Partner
text:
8.3 Discovering WordPress with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Platform Thinking
Ask your AI:
What makes something a "platform" vs just "software"? Use WordPress and Excel as examples.


Exploration 2: Ecosystem Evaluation
Ask your AI:
How do you evaluate whether a WordPress theme or plugin is trustworthy? What red flags should you watch for?


Exploration 3: Architecture
Ask your AI:
Explain WordPress's architecture (database, themes, plugins) using a restaurant analogy
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: WordPress installation, admin interface, themes, basic customisation]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 4 – making and defending technology choices.

Market share: WordPress skills are in demand
Cost: Open source reduces licensing costs
Flexibility: Thousands of plugins for specific needs
Community: Large support ecosystem
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.7 Chapter Summary

WordPress is a platform, not just software
Ecosystem evaluation is a critical skill
Architecture understanding aids troubleshooting
Platform choice is a business decision
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 8  WordPress as Platform
text:
8.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 7, we’ll explore how to extend WordPress through plugins – both using existing ones and understanding how they work. This builds toward customising WordPress for specific business needs.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.1 The Concept First
Platforms become powerful through extensions. WordPress plugins add functionality without changing core code. But when do you use an existing plugin vs build custom? This is a critical business decision.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.2 Understanding Through Build vs Buy
Every extension decision weighs:

Time: How long to build vs install?
Cost: Development vs licensing?
Maintenance: Who updates it?
Fit: Does it solve 80% or 100% of the need?
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
section: 9.3 Discovering Extensions with Your AI Partner
text:
9.3 Discovering Extensions with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Plugin Evaluation
Ask your AI:
I need a contact form for WordPress. Create a framework for evaluating the top 3 options.


Exploration 2: Build vs Buy
Ask your AI:
A client needs a booking system. Walk me through the decision process for using a plugin vs building custom.


Exploration 3: Technical Debt
Ask your AI:
What is "plugin bloat"? How do too many plugins create technical debt?
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Plugin installation, evaluation, basic customisation, child themes, functions.php]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 4 – making and defending technology choices.

ROI calculation: Development cost vs plugin cost
Risk assessment: Plugin abandonment, security
Client communication: Explaining trade-offs
Long-term thinking: Maintenance burden
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.7 Chapter Summary

Extensions multiply platform value
Build vs buy is a business decision
Evaluation frameworks reduce risk
Technical debt accumulates silently
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 9  Extending Platforms
text:
9.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 8, we’ll explore headless architecture – using WordPress as a content backend while building custom frontends. This bridges your CMS knowledge with modern frontend development.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.1 The Concept First
Traditional WordPress handles both content management AND presentation. Headless architecture separates these: WordPress manages content, but a separate frontend (React, for example) handles display.
This enables the best of both worlds.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.2 Understanding Through Separation
Imagine a restaurant where the kitchen (content) and dining room (presentation) are in different buildings. Orders (API requests) travel between them. Each can be optimised independently.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
section: 10.3 Discovering Headless with Your AI Partner
text:
10.3 Discovering Headless with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Architecture Trade-offs
Ask your AI:
Compare traditional WordPress vs headless WordPress. When would you choose each?


Exploration 2: API Contracts
Ask your AI:
Explain how the WordPress REST API works as a "contract" between backend and frontend


Exploration 3: Business Cases
Ask your AI:
Give me 3 real-world scenarios where headless WordPress makes business sense
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: WordPress REST API, endpoints, authentication, fetching data]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.5 Business Applications

Multi-channel: Same content to web, mobile, displays
Performance: Static frontends are faster
Security: Reduced attack surface
Developer experience: Modern frontend tools
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.7 Chapter Summary

Headless separates content from presentation
REST APIs enable this separation
Architecture choices have business implications
The right architecture depends on requirements
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 10  Headless Architecture
text:
10.9 Next Steps
You’ve now mastered content management. In the Business Site Project, you’ll build a complete WordPress site with custom functionality. Then we move to Part III, where we’ll build a modern React frontend that consumes WordPress content.
crumbs: Part II: Content Management for Business

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.1 The Concept First
React introduces component thinking – building interfaces from reusable, self-contained pieces. This isn’t just a technology choice; it’s a different way of thinking about user interfaces.

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.2 Understanding Through LEGO
Think of LEGO bricks. Each brick is self-contained. Complex structures emerge from combining simple pieces. React components work the same way.
A page isn’t a monolith – it’s a composition of components.

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
section: 12.3 Discovering Components with Your AI Partner
text:
12.3 Discovering Components with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Decomposition
Ask your AI:
Look at a typical e-commerce product page. How would you break it into components? Draw a diagram.


Exploration 2: State Thinking
Ask your AI:
Explain React state using a light switch analogy. Then a shopping cart analogy.


Exploration 3: Props Flow
Ask your AI:
Explain how data flows through React components using a family tree analogy

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: JSX, components, props, state, hooks, fetching data]

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.5 Business Applications

Reusability: Build once, use everywhere
Maintainability: Change one component, update everywhere
Team collaboration: Different developers own different components
Testing: Test components in isolation

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.7 Chapter Summary

Components are reusable UI building blocks
State represents what can change
Props pass data between components
Component thinking is a transferable skill

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]

title: 12  Component Thinking: React
text:
12.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 10, we’ll explore CSS frameworks like Bootstrap and Tailwind – tools that accelerate development by providing pre-built components and utility classes. Combined with React, these enable rapid professional development.

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.1 The Concept First
CSS frameworks (Bootstrap, Tailwind, etc.) provide pre-built styles and components. They’re constraints that enable speed. Instead of designing every button, you use consistent, tested patterns.

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.2 Understanding Through Design Systems
Professional design teams use design systems – documented patterns for consistency. CSS frameworks are design systems you can adopt immediately.

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
section: 13.3 Discovering Frameworks with Your AI Partner
text:
13.3 Discovering Frameworks with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Framework Comparison
Ask your AI:
Compare Bootstrap and Tailwind CSS. When would you choose each?


Exploration 2: Constraints as Features
Ask your AI:
How do constraints help creativity? Apply this to CSS frameworks.


Exploration 3: Customisation
Ask your AI:
A client says their Bootstrap site "looks like every other site." How do you respond?

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Bootstrap/Tailwind basics, responsive utilities, component libraries, customisation]

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 4 – making and defending technology choices.

Speed: Faster development time
Consistency: Uniform look and feel
Responsiveness: Built-in mobile support
Maintenance: Updates from community

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.7 Chapter Summary

Frameworks trade flexibility for speed
Design systems enable consistency
Framework choice depends on project needs
Customisation prevents generic appearance

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]

title: 13  Rapid Development: CSS Frameworks
text:
13.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 11, we’ll cover professional practices – testing, version control, and code quality. These practices separate hobbyist projects from professional work.

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.1 The Concept First
Writing code that works is one thing. Writing code that works reliably, can be maintained, and collaborates well is professional practice. This chapter covers the practices that distinguish professional developers.

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.2 Understanding Through Craftsmanship
A carpenter’s table might function whether it’s measured once or twice. But professional carpenters measure twice because they’ve learned the cost of mistakes. Professional practices are your “measure twice.”

title: 14  Professional Practices
section: 14.3 Discovering Professionalism with Your AI Partner
text:
14.3 Discovering Professionalism with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Version Control
Ask your AI:
Explain Git to someone who has never used version control. Why should they care?


Exploration 2: Testing Philosophy
Ask your AI:
Why do professional developers write tests? What's the business case?


Exploration 3: Code Quality
Ask your AI:
What makes code "good"? Create a checklist for reviewing your own code.

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Git workflow, testing basics, code review, documentation]

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 2 – demonstrating professional project management practices.

Risk reduction: Version control prevents disasters
Quality assurance: Testing catches bugs early
Collaboration: Good practices enable teamwork
Maintainability: Future you will thank present you

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.7 Chapter Summary

Version control is non-negotiable
Testing is a professional investment
Code quality serves future maintainers
Professional practices reduce risk

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]

title: 14  Professional Practices
text:
14.9 Next Steps
You’ve now covered modern frontend development. In the React Integration Project, you’ll build a React frontend that consumes WordPress content. Then we move to Part IV, where we look ahead to emerging technologies and your development career.

title: 15  Project: React Integration
text:
15.1 Project Overview
Build a React frontend that consumes content from your WordPress site via the REST API, demonstrating headless architecture and modern frontend development.
Aligned with: Assessment 2 Part B in ISYS3004

title: 15  Project: React Integration
text:

ULO 1: Design and implement effective web applications
ULO 4: Select and integrate technologies
ULO 5: Evaluate emerging technologies

text:

Functional Requirements

Display WordPress posts in React
Post list and detail views
Loading and error states
Responsive design
Navigation between views



Technical Requirements

React (create-react-app or Vite)
WordPress REST API integration
CSS framework (Bootstrap or Tailwind)
Error handling
Component architecture

title: 15  Project: React Integration
text:

Document your React journey:

How did AI help you understand React concepts?
What components did you create vs generate?
How did you debug issues?

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.1 The Concept First
Technology changes constantly. The valuable skill isn’t knowing today’s tools – it’s systematically evaluating new technologies to make informed recommendations. This chapter teaches you how to assess any technology, not just current ones.

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.2 Understanding Through Frameworks
Don’t ask “Is X good?” Ask:

What problem does it solve?
What trade-offs does it make?
Who is using it successfully?
What’s the total cost of adoption?

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
section: 16.3 Discovering Evaluation with Your AI Partner
text:
16.3 Discovering Evaluation with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Evaluation Framework
Ask your AI:
Create a framework for evaluating whether a business should adopt a new web technology


Exploration 2: Hype vs Reality
Ask your AI:
How do you distinguish technology hype from genuine value? Give examples from web development history.


Exploration 3: Current Landscape
Ask your AI:
What web technologies are gaining adoption in 2025? For each, what problem does it solve?

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: PWAs, TypeScript, SSR, evaluation case studies]

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 5 – assessing emerging technologies through systematic evaluation.

Strategic planning: Informed technology roadmaps
Risk management: Understanding adoption risks
Client advisory: Recommending appropriate solutions
Career development: Knowing what to learn next

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.6 Practice Exercises
[Exercises to be developed]

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.7 Chapter Summary

Evaluation frameworks outlast specific technologies
Trade-offs matter more than features
Adoption context determines suitability
Uncertainty is normal – acknowledge it

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.8 Reflection
[Checklist to be developed]

title: 16  Evaluating Emerging Technologies
text:
16.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 13, we’ll focus on your development career – building a portfolio, positioning yourself professionally, and planning continuous growth.

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.1 The Concept First
Technical skills get you interviews. Professional skills get you hired and promoted. This chapter covers the non-technical aspects of a development career: portfolios, networking, communication, and continuous growth.

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.2 Understanding Through Positioning
You’re not just a developer – you’re a professional who solves business problems with technology. How you position yourself matters as much as your technical skills.

title: 17  Your Development Career
section: 17.3 Discovering Career with Your AI Partner
text:
17.3 Discovering Career with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: Portfolio Strategy
Ask your AI:
What should a junior web developer's portfolio demonstrate? Quality vs quantity?


Exploration 2: Professional Communication
Ask your AI:
How do you explain technical decisions to non-technical stakeholders? Give examples.


Exploration 3: Learning Path
Ask your AI:
I know HTML, CSS, JavaScript, WordPress, and React. What should I learn next? How do I decide?

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: Portfolio development, GitHub profile, LinkedIn, networking, interview prep]

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.5 Business Applications
This develops ULO 2 – communicating effectively with stakeholders.

Career progression: From junior to senior roles
Freelance/consulting: Building a client base
Internal advocacy: Getting technical projects approved
Leadership: Moving into management

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.7 Chapter Summary

Portfolio demonstrates capability
Communication multiplies technical value
Networking opens opportunities
Continuous learning is expected

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:

title: 17  Your Development Career
text:
17.9 Next Steps
In Chapter 14, we’ll reflect on what it means to be a developer in the AI era – what won’t change, what’s evolving, and how to thrive in partnership with AI.

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.1 The Concept First
AI is transforming development. But some things won’t change: understanding problems, communicating with stakeholders, making trade-offs, and exercising judgment. This chapter explores what it means to be a developer when AI can write code.

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.2 Understanding Through Partnership
We started this book by establishing AI as your partner. Now let’s reflect: What did you learn that AI couldn’t learn for you? What can you do that AI can’t?

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
section: 18.3 Discovering the Future with Your AI Partner
text:
18.3 Discovering the Future with Your AI Partner

Exploration 1: What Won’t Change
Ask your AI:
What aspects of software development won't be automated by AI? Why?


Exploration 2: Your Unique Value
Ask your AI:
What can a human developer do that AI cannot? Be specific.


Exploration 3: Future Partnership
Ask your AI:
How might human-AI collaboration in development evolve over the next 5 years?

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.4 From Concept to Code
[To be developed: AI collaboration patterns, prompt engineering, quality control, ethical considerations]

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.5 Business Applications

Productivity: Leveraging AI effectively
Quality control: Reviewing AI output critically
Innovation: Using AI for exploration
Leadership: Guiding AI-assisted teams

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:

[Exercises to be developed]

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.7 Chapter Summary

AI amplifies, doesn’t replace, human judgment
Understanding problems remains essential
Communication skills gain value
Continuous adaptation is the new normal

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.8 Reflection
Looking back on your journey:

Can you articulate what you learned that AI couldn’t learn for you?
Do you understand your unique value as a developer?
Have you developed judgment about when to use AI and when not to?
Are you ready to continue learning independently?

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.9 Your Final Learning Journal Entry
Record your thoughts on:

Your journey: What surprised you most about learning web development?
AI partnership: How did your relationship with AI tools evolve?
Business thinking: How do you now think about technology decisions?
Future goals: Where will you go from here?

title: 18  The AI-Era Developer
text:
18.10 Looking Forward
This book ends, but your learning continues. You now have:

Technical foundations in web development
Business thinking about technology decisions
AI collaboration skills for the modern era
Professional practices for quality work

Use these foundations. Build things. Break things. Learn from mistakes. Partner with AI. Create value.
Welcome to your career as a web professional.
